poem:
The Senate Dance

A bill, "big, beautiful," they say,  
with whispers of welfare's fall this day—  
Fifty-one raise hands, forty-nine delay,  
a dance of numbers swayed this way.  

In hallowed halls, the vote unfurled,  
shaping currents in this tilted world.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Trump news at a glance: president’s ‘big, beautiful bill’ clears first Senate hurdle After a scramble in the Senate, Republicans voted on Saturday to advance Trump’s signature “big, beautiful” bill, with a 51-49 vote. Republicans had been divided over the controversial bill, with some rejecting the proposal to cut welfare programmes in order to cover tax breaks, and others demanding deeper cuts. The key procedural hurdle was cleared hours after the debate opened, with two". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
